resources.string: Automated Arabica Coffee Leaf Disease Recognition System

CafeTech is a detection system designed to help Arabica coffee growers automatically identify diseases on their crops.\n\nThis system uses Artificial Intelligence (AI) in identifying diseases on a taken image of an Arabica Coffee Leaf. The mobile application then displays basic information and recommendation for control and management of the identified disease.
Keep it going! Your Arabica crop shows no signs of infestation.

Caused by pests called 'PeriLeucoptera coffeella'.

It is recognizable on the upper surface of the infested leaf by the large, irregular brown spots. Interacting with the spot exposes the small white caterpillars under the upper epidermis of the leaf.

The total life cycle of the pests depends on temperature, relative humidity, and rainfall. Attacks are usually stronger during the dry season than in wet periods.

Caused by pests called 'Hemilia vastarix'.

It can be recognized through the upper leaf surface by the pale yellow spots and through the undersides of the leaf by the powdery orange-yellow lesions.

Occurs mainly during the rainy season and when exposed to moisture for a long period.

Caused by pests called 'Cercospora coffeicola'.

The most common symptoms are circular spots with tan, grey, or white centers. Lesions are often surrounded by light yellowish "halo", which is more visible on the upper leaf surface.

This usually happens in cooler, wet areas above 600 meters.

Caused by pests called 'Phoma costaricensis'.

The disease can be recognized from the dark-colored patches that usually start at the leaf edges. Under high humidity, small black spots on the lesions are observed.

Occurs with great severity under conditions of temperature between 16 and 20 degree Celsius, associated with cold winds and fine rains.
Consider using fungicides such as Thiamethoxam, Chlorantraniliprole, and Cartap hydrochloride.
Consider using fungicides such as \"Copper-containing fungicides\" (Copper oxychloride and Cuprous Oxide).

Consider using fungicides such as Kocide fungicides.\n\nMake sure to promote healthy air circulation through pruning plants and remove seed debris afterward. Additionally, make sure to arrange the spacing of the plants properly.

Using fungicides to control this disease is not recommendable. Instead, crops must be implemented in areas with opposing conditions in favor of the disease. Make sure to avoid shady places and avoid excess nitrogen fertilization.
